questiontext.text:
A machine fills milk into \(125\)ml packages. It is suspected that the machine is not working correctly and that the amount of milk filled differs from the setpoint \(\mu_0 = 125\). A sample of \(184\) packages filled by the machine are collected. The sample mean \(\bar{y}\) is equal to \(121.4\) and the sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(11.79\).

Test the hypothesis that the amount filled corresponds on average to the setpoint. What is the absolute value of the \(t\) test statistic?

generalfeedback.text: The \(t\) test statistic is calculated by: \[\begin{aligned} t & = & \frac{\bar y - \mu_0}{\sqrt{\frac{s^2_{n-1}}{n}}} = \frac{121.4 - 125}{\sqrt{\frac{11.79}{184}}} = -14.222.\end{aligned}\] The absolute value of the \(t\) test statistic is thus equal to \(14.222\).

questiontext.text:
A machine fills milk into \(500\)ml packages. It is suspected that the machine is not working correctly and that the amount of milk filled differs from the setpoint \(\mu_0 = 500\). A sample of \(120\) packages filled by the machine are collected. The sample mean \(\bar{y}\) is equal to \(470.5\) and the sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(780.23\).

Test the hypothesis that the amount filled corresponds on average to the setpoint. What is the absolute value of the \(t\) test statistic?

generalfeedback.text: The \(t\) test statistic is calculated by: \[\begin{aligned} t & = & \frac{\bar y - \mu_0}{\sqrt{\frac{s^2_{n-1}}{n}}} = \frac{470.5 - 500}{\sqrt{\frac{780.23}{120}}} = -11.569.\end{aligned}\] The absolute value of the \(t\) test statistic is thus equal to \(11.569\).

questiontext.text:
A machine fills milk into \(250\)ml packages. It is suspected that the machine is not working correctly and that the amount of milk filled differs from the setpoint \(\mu_0 = 250\). A sample of \(205\) packages filled by the machine are collected. The sample mean \(\bar{y}\) is equal to \(227.1\) and the sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(42\).

Test the hypothesis that the amount filled corresponds on average to the setpoint. What is the absolute value of the \(t\) test statistic?

generalfeedback.text: The \(t\) test statistic is calculated by: \[\begin{aligned} t & = & \frac{\bar y - \mu_0}{\sqrt{\frac{s^2_{n-1}}{n}}} = \frac{227.1 - 250}{\sqrt{\frac{42}{205}}} = -50.593.\end{aligned}\] The absolute value of the \(t\) test statistic is thus equal to \(50.593\).

questiontext.text:
A machine fills milk into \(1000\)ml packages. It is suspected that the machine is not working correctly and that the amount of milk filled differs from the setpoint \(\mu_0 = 1000\). A sample of \(157\) packages filled by the machine are collected. The sample mean \(\bar{y}\) is equal to \(951.2\) and the sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(984.12\).

Test the hypothesis that the amount filled corresponds on average to the setpoint. What is the value of the \(t\) test statistic?

generalfeedback.text:
The \(t\) test statistic is calculated by: \[\begin{aligned} t & = & \frac{\bar y - \mu_0}{\sqrt{\frac{s^2_{n-1}}{n}}} = \frac{951.2 - 1000}{\sqrt{\frac{984.12}{157}}} = -19.492.\end{aligned}\] The \(t\) test statistic is thus equal to \(-19.492\).

  1. False
  2. True
  3. False
  4. False
  5. False

questiontext.text:
A machine fills milk into \(500\)ml packages. It is suspected that the machine is not working correctly and that the amount of milk filled differs from the setpoint \(\mu_0 = 500\). A sample of \(188\) packages filled by the machine are collected. The sample mean \(\bar{y}\) is equal to \(539.2\) and the sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(824.26\).

Test the hypothesis that the amount filled corresponds on average to the setpoint. What is the value of the \(t\) test statistic?

generalfeedback.text:
The \(t\) test statistic is calculated by: \[\begin{aligned} t & = & \frac{\bar y - \mu_0}{\sqrt{\frac{s^2_{n-1}}{n}}} = \frac{539.2 - 500}{\sqrt{\frac{824.26}{188}}} = 18.721.\end{aligned}\] The \(t\) test statistic is thus equal to \(18.721\).

  1. False
  2. False
  3. True
  4. False
  5. False

questiontext.text:
A machine fills milk into \(200\)ml packages. It is suspected that the machine is not working correctly and that the amount of milk filled differs from the setpoint \(\mu_0 = 200\). A sample of \(185\) packages filled by the machine are collected. The sample mean \(\bar{y}\) is equal to \(201.4\) and the sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(86.97\).

Test the hypothesis that the amount filled corresponds on average to the setpoint. What is the value of the \(t\) test statistic?

generalfeedback.text:
The \(t\) test statistic is calculated by: \[\begin{aligned} t & = & \frac{\bar y - \mu_0}{\sqrt{\frac{s^2_{n-1}}{n}}} = \frac{201.4 - 200}{\sqrt{\frac{86.97}{185}}} = 2.042.\end{aligned}\] The \(t\) test statistic is thus equal to \(2.042\).

  1. False
  2. False
  3. False
  4. True
  5. False

questiontext.text: In the following figure the distributions of a variable given by two samples (A and B) are represented by parallel boxplots. Which of the following statements are correct? (Comment: The statements are either about correct or clearly wrong.)

generalfeedback.text:
1. False. Distribution B has on average higher values than distribution A.
  2. True. Both distributions have no observations which deviate more than 1.5 times the interquartile range from the box.
  3. False. The interquartile range in sample A is
    emphnot clearly bigger than in B.
  4. True. The skewness of both distributions is similar, both are left-skewed.
  5. True. Distribution B is left-skewed.

answer.text: The location of both distributions is about the same.

feedback.text: False. Distribution B has on average higher values than distribution A.
True. Both distributions have no observations which deviate more than 1.5 times the interquartile range from the box.

answer.text: The spread in sample A is clearly bigger than in B.

feedback.text:
False. The interquartile range in sample A is
emphnot clearly bigger than in B.

answer.text: The skewness of both samples is similar.

feedback.text: True. The skewness of both distributions is similar, both are left-skewed.

questiontext.text: In the following figure the distributions of a variable given by two samples (A and B) are represented by parallel boxplots. Which of the following statements are correct? (Comment: The statements are either about correct or clearly wrong.)

generalfeedback.text:
1. False. Distribution A has on average higher values than distribution B.
  2. False. There are observations which deviate more than 1.5 times the interquartile range from the median.
  3. True. The interquartile range in sample A is clearly bigger than in B.
  4. True. The skewness of both distributions is similar, both are about symmetric.
  5. True. Distribution A is about symmetric.

questiontext.text: What is the name of the R function for extracting the estimated coefficients from a fitted (generalized) linear model object?

generalfeedback.text: coef is the R function for extracting the estimated coefficients from a fitted (generalized) linear model object. See ?coef for the corresponding manual page.

questiontext.text: What is the name of the R function for extracting the estimated coefficients from a fitted (generalized) linear model object?

generalfeedback.text: coef is the R function for extracting the estimated coefficients from a fitted (generalized) linear model object. See ?coef for the corresponding manual page.

questiontext.text: What is the name of the R function for extracting the regressor matrix from a fitted (generalized) linear model object?

generalfeedback.text: model.matrix is the R function for extracting the regressor matrix from a fitted (generalized) linear model object. See ?model.matrix for the corresponding manual page.

questiontext.text:
For the 38 observations of the variable x in the data file boxhist.csv draw a histogram, a boxplot and a stripchart. Based on the graphics, answer the following questions or check the correct statements, respectively. (Comment: The tolerance for numeric answers is \(\pm0.6\), the true/false statements are either about correct or clearly wrong.)

  1. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The distribution is unimodal.~%100%The distribution is not unimodal.}
  2. {1:MULTICHOICE:%100%The distribution is symmetric.~%0%The distribution is right-skewed.~%0%The distribution is left-skewed.}
  3. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The boxplot shows outliers.~%100%The boxplot shows no outliers.}
  4. A quarter of the observations is smaller than which value? {1:NUMERICAL:=1.95:0.6}
  5. A quarter of the observations is greater than which value? {1:NUMERICAL:=13.9:0.6}
  6. Half of the observations are smaller than which value? {1:NUMERICAL:=3.2:0.6}

generalfeedback.text:
1. False. / True.
  2. True. / False. / False.
  3. False. / True.
  4. 1.95.
  5. 13.9.
  6. 3.2.

Based on the graphics, answer the following questions or check the correct statements, respectively. questiontext.text: On 2013-05-03 one Euro (€) was buying 1.3109 US Dollars ($) and 0.8431 British Pounds (£). At Frankfurter Börse around noon adidas AG was the largest winner compared with the day before with a price of € 84.8492 per share. If you buy 28 shares, how much are they worth in $?

generalfeedback.text: The worth in $ is the number of shares \(\times\) stock price \(\times\) exchange rate, i.e., \(28 \times 84.8492 \times 1.3109 \approx 3114.407\).

questiontext.text: On 2013-05-03 one Euro (€) was buying 1.3109 US Dollars ($) and 0.8431 British Pounds (£). At Frankfurter Börse around noon adidas AG was the largest winner compared with the day before with a price of € 84.8492 per share. If you buy 93 shares, how much are they worth in $?

generalfeedback.text: The worth in $ is the number of shares \(\times\) stock price \(\times\) exchange rate, i.e., \(93 \times 84.8492 \times 1.3109 \approx 10344.28\).

questiontext.text: On 2013-05-03 one Euro (€) was buying 1.3109 US Dollars ($) and 0.8431 British Pounds (£). At Frankfurter Börse around noon adidas AG was the largest winner compared with the day before with a price of € 84.8492 per share. If you buy 95 shares, how much are they worth in £?

generalfeedback.text: The worth in £ is the number of shares \(\times\) stock price \(\times\) exchange rate, i.e., \(95 \times 84.8492 \times 0.8431 \approx 6795.954\).
